an3.67:1.1: “There are, mendicants, these three topics of discussion.
an3.67:1.4: ‘That is how it was in the past.’

an3.67:2.1: You can know whether or not an individual is competent to hold a discussion by seeing how they take part in a discussion.
an3.67:2.2: When an individual is asked a question, if it needs to be answered categorically and they don’t answer it categorically; or if it needs analysis and they answer without analyzing it; or if it needs a counter-question and they answer without a counter-question; or if it should be set aside and they don’t set it aside, then that individual is not competent to hold a discussion.
an3.67:2.3: When an individual is asked a question, if it needs to be answered categorically and they answer it categorically; or if it needs analysis and they answer after analyzing it; or if it needs a counter-question and they answer with a counter-question; or if it should be set aside and they set it aside, then that individual is competent to hold a discussion.
an3.67:3.1: You can know whether or not an individual is competent to hold a discussion by seeing how they take part in a discussion.
an3.67:3.2: When an individual is asked a question, if they’re not consistent about what their position is and what it isn’t; about what they propose; about speaking from what they know; and about the appropriate procedure, then that individual is not competent to hold a discussion.
an3.67:3.3: When an individual is asked a question, if they are consistent about what their position is and what it isn’t; about what they propose; about speaking from what they know; and about the appropriate procedure, then that individual is competent to hold a discussion.
an3.67:4.1: You can know whether or not an individual is competent to hold a discussion by seeing how they take part in a discussion.
an3.67:4.2: When an individual is asked a question, if they dodge the issue; distract the discussion with irrelevant points; or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness, then that individual is not competent to hold a discussion.
an3.67:4.3: When an individual is asked a question, if they don’t dodge the issue; distract the discussion with irrelevant points; or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness, then that individual is competent to hold a discussion.
an3.67:5.1: You can know whether or not an individual is competent to hold a discussion by seeing how they take part in a discussion.
an3.67:5.2: When an individual is asked a question, if they intimidate, crush, mock, or seize on trivial mistakes, then that individual is not competent to hold a discussion.
an3.67:5.3: When an individual is asked a question, if they don’t intimidate, crush, mock, or seize on trivial mistakes, then that individual is competent to hold a discussion.
an3.67:6.1: You can know whether or not an individual has what’s required by seeing how they take part in a discussion.
an3.67:6.2: If they actively listen they have what’s required; if they don’t actively listen they don’t have what’s required.
an3.67:6.3: Someone who has what’s required directly knows one thing, completely understands one thing, gives up one thing, and realizes one thing—
an3.67:6.4: and then they experience complete freedom.
an3.67:6.5: This is the purpose of discussion,
an3.67:6.8: and listening well, that is, the liberation of the mind by not grasping.
